content: [Moderator hat on] It all depends. If you were on some sort of medication (doctor prescribed) that caused the discoloration, then they may pay for it. If it is for cosmetic reasons, then I doubt it. Each military treatment facility is different. Some will use it as a training opportunity for their residents and some will not allow it if the Dental Clinic Commander has a very strict set of guidelines. My recommendation would be to contact the dental clinic and explain the situation. If it is strictly for cosmetic reasons, then my bet is on them saying "no". Good luck. [Moderator hat still on]
reply: [Moderator hat on] It all depends. If you were on some sort of medication (doctor prescribed) that caused the discoloration, then they may pay for it. If it is for cosmetic reasons, then I doubt it. Each military treatment facility is different. Some will use it as a training opportunity for their residents and some will not allow it if the Dental Clinic Commander has a very strict set of guidelines. My recommendation would be to contact the dental clinic and explain the situation. If it is strictly for cosmetic reasons, then my bet is on them saying "no". Good luck. [Moderator hat still on]
title: dental

content: It also depends on if you are AD or a dependent. Dependents are not always seen at on base clinics, they have United Concordia to see a regular dentist and there is a $1200 cap each year on approved work. Usually it isn't and it will come out of pocket.

content: The only tooth I ever lost was because of a poorly done root canal by an Army dentist in Germany. Had to have it jerked out with no novacanine while standing in front of a window of a old wrecked building in Grafenwohr for light. And this guy wants the Army to whiten his teeth.... He'll be lucky if he don't get them shot out! What does he think joining the Army is about - trying out for American Idol? Wandering and Wondering
